abstract: Bank of America’s new chief, Brian Moynihan, in many ways has had a career of falling into bigger jobs at the bank when executives were fired or shunted aside.
snippet: Bank of America’s new chief, Brian Moynihan, in many ways has had a career of falling into bigger jobs at the bank when executives were fired or shunted aside.
lead_paragraph: As Bank of America scrambled this week to appoint a new chief executive, one of the bank’s longtime soldiers  Brian T. Moynihan  stood by ready and willing to take a job that others had turned down.

headline.main: At Bank of America, a Chief Steps in Where Few Can
headline.print_headline: At Bank of America, a Chief Steps In Where Few Can

abstract: In the lucrative business of underwriting and selling a company’s stock, J.P. Morgan led the world’s banks this year, earning an estimated $2.2 billion in fees, or nearly double what it hauled from the deals last year.
snippet: In the lucrative business of underwriting and selling a company’s stock, J.P. Morgan led the world’s banks this year, earning an estimated $2.2 billion in fees, or nearly double what it hauled from the deals last year.
lead_paragraph: In the lucrative business of underwriting and selling a company’s stock, JPMorgan led the world’s banks this year, earning an estimated $2.2 billion in fees, or nearly double what it hauled from the deals last year.

headline.main: JPMorgan Tops Rankings, With $2.2 Billion In Fees

headline.main: BofA’s New Chief Got Job When Others Fell Away

abstract: Pay czar Kenneth Feinberg’s reaction to the compensation proposed by Robert Kelly caused Bank of America’s search committee think again about trying to hire the Bank of New York Mellon chief executive as its next C.E.O., The Wall Street Journal reported.
snippet: Pay czar Kenneth Feinberg’s reaction to the compensation proposed by Robert Kelly caused Bank of America’s search committee think again about trying to hire the Bank of New York Mellon chief executive as its next C.E.O., The Wall Street Journal re...
lead_paragraph: Pay czar Kenneth Feinberg’s reaction to the compensation proposed by Robert Kelly caused  Bank of America‘s search committee to think again about trying to hire the Bank of New York Mellon chief executive as its next C.E.O., The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people close to the talks.

headline.main: Payout Politics Behind BofA’s C.E.O. Search

abstract: Citigroup’s massive stock sale this week may not have been a big hit with investors, but it helped its capital markets bankers look a lot more successful this year.

headline.main: Another Benefit to Citi’s Stock Sale: Bragging Rights
